questions.text: Which structure forms the lateral wall of the anterior horn of the lateral ventricle?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Head of the caudate nucleus

Explanation:

Relations of Lateral Ventricles

Corpus Callosum

(Option A ruled out)

Caudate Nucleus

(Option B)
  • Roof of the body of lateral ventricle
  • Roof, floor and Anterior Wall of the Frontal horn
  • Roof, medial and lateral wall of Occipital horn
  • Lateral part of the Roof of the Temporal Horn
  • Head - Lateral wall and floor of Anterior Horn
  • Body - Part of the Floor of the body of the Lateral ventricle
  • Tail - Roof of inferior/temporal horn

 Caudate nucleus and Lateral Ventricle

Corpus callosum and Lateral Ventricle 

Thalamus (Option C): The thalamus forms the walls of the third ventricle and does not form part of the lateral wall of the anterior horn of the lateral ventricle.

Hippocampus (Option D): The hippocampus is located in the inferior (temporal) horn of the lateral ventricle and does not form the lateral wall of the anterior horn.

questions.text: Which cranial nerve sensory fibres transmit sensory information from the skin and mucous membranes of the face, head, and neck?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) General Somatic Afferent (GSA) fibres

 

Explanation:

  • GSA fibres carry sensory input like pain, temperature, touch, and proprioception from the skin, mucous membranes, and other somatic regions of the face, head, and neck.
  • The sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve processes this input.
  • Cranial Nerves involved in GSA - Trigeminal (V), Facial (VII), Glossopharyngeal (IX), Vagus (X).

 

Special Somatic Afferent (SSA) fibres (Option A):

  • SSA fibres transmit information related to special senses like vision and hearing, not the general sensations of touch and pain.

 

General Visceral Afferent (GVA) fibres (Option B):

  • GVA fibres carry sensory information from internal organs, like the lungs and stomach, not the skin and mucous membranes.
  • Cranial Nerves involved in GVA - Glossopharyngeal (IX), Vagus (X).

 

Special Visceral Afferent (SVA) fibres (Option C):

  • SVA fibres are involved in special senses such as taste and smell, not general sensory functions like pain or temperature.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with severe headaches, vomiting, and papilloedema. Imaging reveals obstructive hydrocephalus due to a tumour blocking the exit of cerebrospinal fluid from the fourth ventricle. Which of the following structures is most likely blocked?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Foramina of Luschka
 

Explanation:

The foramina of Luschka and the Foramen of Magendie allow CSF to exit from the fourth ventricle into the subarachnoid space, and their obstruction can lead to hydrocephalus.

 

Foramen of Magendie and Luschka:

 

Aspect

Foramen of Magendie

(Median aperture)

Foramina of Luschka

(Lateral aperture)

Location

Caudal to the cerebellar nodule

At the ends of the lateral recesses of the 4th ventricle.

Function

Main communication between ventricles and subarachnoid space

Allow communication between the fourth ventricle and the subarachnoid space.

Associated Pathology

Obstruction leads to hydrocephalus.

 

A blockage here would prevent CSF from exiting medially into the subarachnoid space.

Obstruction leads to hydrocephalus.

 

A blockage here prevents CSF from exiting laterally from the fourth ventricle.

Symptoms of Obstruction

Headache, vomiting, papilloedema

Headache, vomiting, papilloedema

 

The Foramen of Monro (Option A): Also known as the interventricular foramen, connects the lateral ventricles to the third ventricle, not the fourth ventricle.

Foramen rotundum (Option C): It is an opening in the sphenoid bone of the skull. It transmits the maxillary nerve (V2) and is unrelated to CSF flow or the ventricular system.

Foramen ovale (Option D): This is also an opening in the sphenoid bone of the skull. It transmits the mandibular nerve (V3) and is not involved in CSF drainage from the fourth ventricle.

questions.text: Which of the given options are correctly matched based on the image given?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 2- Fourth Ventricle, 4- Aqueduct

Explanation:

  • Each cerebral hemisphere contains one of the two large lateral ventricles. This ventricle is roughly C-shaped and can be divided into several sections.
    • Body
    • Anterior horn - extends into the frontal lobe
    • Posterior horn -extends into the Occipital lobe
    • Inferior horn - extends into the Temporal lobe
  • The third ventricle is a narrow space located between the two thalami. It connects to the lateral ventricles in the front via the interventricular foramina (of Monro) and to the fourth ventricle in the back through the cerebral aqueduct (of Sylvius).
  • The cerebral aqueduct, also known as the aqueduct of Sylvius, is a narrow passage approximately 1.8 cm long that links the third ventricle to the fourth ventricle.
  • The fourth ventricle is sandwiched between the brainstem and the cerebellum.
  • From the fourth ventricle, the CSF moves into the central canal of the spinal cord.

questions.text: What is a primary characteristic of Benign External Hydrocephalus (BEH) in infants?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Macrocephaly without significant symptoms

 

Explanation:

  • BEH in infants is defined by an increase in head size (macrocephaly) without accompanying significant neurological symptoms.
  • It is often self-limiting and can be monitored.

 

Benign External Hydrocephalus

Definition

Increase in subarachnoid space volume with minimal ventricular enlargement, leading to macrocephaly (large head).

Causes
  • Impaired CSF absorption because of arachnoid villi immaturity
  • Venous defects

Clinical features
  • Increased head circumference- raised ICP
  • Poor motor development
  • Hypotonia, vomiting and seizures.

Investigations
  • Through CT or MRI imaging showing subarachnoid space widening;
  • Clinical assessment.

Treatment
  • Conservative Observation: For cases without significant symptoms.
  • Surgical Options: Considered if increased ICP or other complications are present (e.g., ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

 

Severe neurological symptoms (Option A): BEH is characterized by macrocephaly without significant neurological symptoms. Infants with BEH typically do not exhibit major cognitive or physical impairments.

 

Necessitates immediate surgical intervention (Option C):

  • BEH generally does not require immediate surgical intervention.
  • Most cases are mild and self-resolving; surgery is only considered if there are complications or increased intracranial pressure.

 

Increased ventricular enlargement (Option D):

  • In BEH, there is an increase in the subarachnoid space volume with minimal or no enlargement of the ventricles.
  • This distinguishes it from other types of hydrocephalus where ventricular enlargement is more prominent.

questions.text:
Match the following wall of the 3rd ventricle with its respective component.


	
		
			
			1. Anterior wall
			
			
			a) Hypothalamus
			
		
		
			
			2. Posterior Wall
			
			
			b) Mammillary bodies
			
		
		
			
			3. Lateral wall
			
			
			c) Lamina terminalis
			
		
		
			
			4. Floor
			
			
			d) Pineal gland
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b

 

Explanation:

  • The Third ventricle is a cavity located in the diencephalon. It is a narrow, midline space positioned between the two thalami and part of the hypothalamus.
  • It connects to the lateral ventricle via the interventricular foramen (of Monro) anteriorly, and posteriorly, it connects to the fourth ventricle through the cerebral aqueduct (of Sylvius).
  • It has an anterior wall, posterior wall, roof, floor and two lateral walls.

 

Wall of 3rd Ventricle

Components

Anterior Wall
  • Anterior column of fornix
  • Anterior commissure
  • Lamina terminalis

Posterior Wall
  • Pineal gland
  • Posterior commissure
  • Commencement of cerebral aqueduct

Roof

Formed by the ependyma that stretches across the upper limits of two thalami

Floor
  • Optic chiasma
  • Tuber cinereum and infundibulum
  • Mammillary bodies
  • Posterior perforated substance
  • Tegmentum of the midbrain

Lateral Walls
  • Divided by Hypothalamic sulcus into:
    • Large superior part- Medial surface of the thalamus.
    • Small inferior part- Hypothalamus and it is continuous with the ventricular floor.

 

  • Corpora arenacea, or brain sand, are calcified deposits in the pineal gland composed of calcium salts. They are a common and typically benign finding in the brain, particularly in older individuals.
  • Corpora arenacea can be seen as an opacity in the pineal gland area on radiological imaging, especially on X-rays, CT scans, or MRI.

questions.text:
Match the following boundary of the 4th ventricle with its component.

 


	
		
			
			1. Lateral wall
			
			
			a) Superior medullary velum
			
		
		
			
			2. Posterior wall
			
			
			b) Superior medulla
			
		
		
			
			3. Rhomboid fossa
			
			
			c) Superior cerebellar peduncle
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1-c, 2-a, 3-b

 

Explanation:

  • The fourth ventricle is a tent-shaped cavity filled with cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
  • It is located anterior to the cerebellum and posterior to the pons and the upper part of the medulla oblongata.
  • The ventricle is lined with ependyma.
  • It connects above to the cerebral aqueduct of the midbrain.
  • It connects below to the central canal of the medulla oblongata and the spinal cord.
  • The ventricle has lateral boundaries, a roof, and a rhomboid-shaped floor.


 

Boundaries of 4th Ventricle

Description

Lateral Wall
  • Inferolaterally- Inferior cerebellar peduncle, and gracile and cuneate tubercles
  • Superolaterally- Superior cerebellar peduncle

Roof (Posterior Wall)
  • Superior Part:
    • Medial borders of the two superior cerebellar peduncles.
    • Superior medullary velum (a sheet of white matter).
  • Inferior Part:
    • Inferior medullary velum (ventricular ependyma and pia mater)
    • Median aperture (foramen of Magendie) in the midline.
  • Lateral Recesses:
    • Extend laterally around the medulla.
    • Open anteriorly as the foramina of Luschka (lateral openings of the fourth ventricle).

Rhomboid Fossa (Floor)
  • The posterior surface of the pons
  • The upper part of the medulla

questions.text: Which structure in the floor of the 4th ventricle consists of transverse white fibres derived from the arcuate nuclei?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Stria medullaris

 

Explanation:

The stria medullaris consists of transverse white fibres originating from the arcuate nuclei, which cross the floor of the 4th ventricle to enter the inferior cerebellar peduncle.

 

Structures and relation with the 4th Ventricle

 

  • The floor of the 4th ventricle is divided into right and left halves by the median sulcus, extending from the aqueduct to the central canal.
  • Stria Medullaris: White fibres (derived from arcuate nuclei) cross the floor and enter the inferior cerebellar peduncle.
  • Medial Eminence: Longitudinal elevation on either side of the median sulcus, bounded laterally by the sulcus limitans. (Option A ruled out)
  • Vestibular Area: Lateral to sulcus limitans, it overlies the vestibular nuclei.
  • Superior Fovea & Locus Ceruleus: At the upper sulcus limitans, the superior fovea is a triangular depression; locus ceruleus is a bluish-grey area due to pigmented nerve cells. (Option C ruled out)
  • Facial Colliculus: Oval swelling in the pontine floor produced by facial nerve fibres looping over the abducent nucleus.
  • Hypoglossal and Vagal Triangles: Located in the medullary part of the floor; the hypoglossal triangle overlies the hypoglossal nucleus, and the vagal triangle overlies the vagus, glossopharyngeal, and accessory nerve nuclei.
  • Area Postrema: A small area between the vagal triangle and the gracile tubercle. (Option D ruled out)
  • Obex: A fold formed by the meeting of two teniae at the inferior angle, marking the lower part of the ventricle.
  • Central Canal: Opens into the 4th ventricle superiorly, extends through the medulla and spinal cord, lined with ependyma but lacks a choroid plexus.

questions.text: Which of the following does not cross the midline?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Arcuate Fasciculus

Explanation:

  • The Arcuate Fasciculus is an association tract that connects different areas within the same hemisphere and does not cross the midline.
  • The white matter in the cerebral hemispheres consists of long, myelinated axons bundled into larger tracts called fasciculi.
  • These white matter tracts are classified as association, commissural, or projection pathways based on where they start, travel, and end.

Commissural fibres

Projection

They connect one hemisphere to the opposite side, linking corresponding (homotopic) or different (heterotopic) areas. 

  • Corpus Callosum: The largest commissural structure connecting the two cerebral hemispheres, located at the bottom of the longitudinal fissure. (Option A ruled out)
  • Anterior Commissure: A smaller bundle of nerve fibres crossing the midline at the lamina terminalis.(Option B ruled out)
  • Fornix: Composed of myelinated fibres, it connects the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies in the hypothalamus. It connects the hippocampal formations of the 2 sides. (Option C ruled out)

Projection fibres connect the cerebral cortex with subcortical structures, including the brainstem and spinal cord, and include both descending (corticofugal) and ascending (corticopetal) fibres.

These fibres converge in the corona radiata, pass through the internal capsule, and are flanked by the caudate nucleus and thalamus medially, and the lentiform nucleus laterally.

questions.text: Which association fibre connects Wernicke's area with Broca's area
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Arcuate Fasciculus

Explanation:

The Arcuate Fasciculus connects Wernicke's area, located in the superior temporal gyrus and responsible for language comprehension, with Broca's area, found in the inferior frontal gyrus and involved in language production.

Association Tracts

  • Association tracts connect different areas within the same hemisphere, with short U-fibers linking nearby gyri and long fibres connecting gyri across different lobes.
  • Short fibres are closer to the surface, near the cortex, while longer fibres run deeper within the white matter, allowing for fast communication and sensory processing.
  • Examples of association tracts are:

Arcuate fasciculus

Uncinate fasciculus

(Option A ruled out)

Inferior and Superior longitudinal fasciculus

(Option B & D ruled out)
  • It is seen on the left side of the cerebrum.
  • In 95% of people, the language area is on the left dominant hemisphere.
  • Wernicke's sensory speech area in the temporal lobe is connected with Broca's motor speech area in the inferior frontal gyrus by arcuate fasciculus.
  • It does not cross the midline.
  • Connecting the temporal lobe with the frontal lobe.
  • It does not cross the midline.
  • Superior longitudinal fasciculus: Connects the anterior part of the frontal lobe to the occipital and temporal lobes.
  • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus: Connects the occipital lobe to the temporal lobe.
  • They do not cross the midline.

questions.text: Which part of the corpus callosum contains fibres that connect the right and left occipital cortices?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Splenium

Explanation:

  • The splenium is part of the corpus callosum where fibers connect the right occipital cortex with the left occipital cortex.
  • Corpus callosum is the largest commissure of the brain and connects the two cerebral hemispheres.

Corpus callosum

Parts

  • Rostrum (anterior): Axons here connect the orbitofrontal cortex on the right and left side. (Option A ruled out)
  • Genu: Most anterior portion of the corpus callosum; forms the anterior wall of the frontal horn of the lateral ventricle and contains fibres that connect the prefrontal cortex. (Option B ruled out)
  • Body (central part): It connects motor and premotor areas in the frontal and parietal lobes (Option C ruled out)
  • Splenium (posterior): Axons connect the right occipital cortex with the left occipital cortex.

Corpus Callosum Fibers:

  • Frontal Forceps (Forceps Minor):
    • Connects the frontal lobes across hemispheres
    • Fibers pass through the genu of the corpus callosum
  • Occipital Forceps (Forceps Major):
    • Connects the occipital visual cortices across hemispheres
    • Fibers pass through the splenium of the corpus callosum

Tapetum Fibers: Fibres from splenium and isthmus that arc forward along the lateral wall of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle.

questions.text: Which cranial nerve motor fibres are responsible for innervating skeletal muscles that develop from somites?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) General Somatic Efferent (GSE) fibers

 

Explanation:

 

Motor Neural Columns
 

GSE (General Somatic Efferent)

(Option A)

GVE (General Visceral Efferent)

(Option C ruled out)

SVE (Special Visceral Efferent )

(Option B ruled out)

Innervation

Motor innervation to skeletal muscles that develop from somites.

Autonomic (involuntary) innervation to smooth muscles and glands.

Innervate muscles that are derived from pharyngeal arches, not somites.

Function

Voluntary movements such as eye and tongue movements.

Functions such as pupil constriction, salivation, digestion, and heart rate regulation.

Functions like facial expression, mastication, and swallowing.

Nerves
  • Oculomotor (III)
  • Trochlear (IV)
  • Abducens (VI)
  • Hypoglossal (XII)
  • Oculomotor (III)
  • Facial (VII)
  • Glossopharyngeal (IX)
  • Vagus (X)
  • Facial (VII)
  • Trigeminal (V)
  • Accessory spinal nerve (XI)

Neural Columns

Special Somatic Afferent (SSA) fibres (Option D):

  • SSA fibres are not motor but sensory, transmitting sensory information related to vision and hearing.
  • These fibres are involved in processing external stimuli rather than controlling motor functions.

questions.text: Which cranial nerve sensory fibres are primarily responsible for transmitting taste sensations from the tongue to the brainstem?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Special Visceral Afferent (SVA) fibres

 

Explanation:

 

Special Sensory Column

Special Visceral Afferent (SVA) fibres

(Option B)

Special Somatic Afferent (SSA) fibres

(Option A ruled out)
  • SVA fibres are sensory fibres responsible for transmitting taste sensations from the tongue to the brainstem.
  • These fibres terminate in the nucleus solitarius in the medulla
  • Cranial nerves - Facial (VII), Glossopharyngeal (IX).
  • SSA fibres are responsible for transmitting sensory information related to the special senses of smell, vision, hearing, and balance.
  • The optic nerve (II), olfactory nerve (III), vestibulocochlear nerve (VIII) are part of SSA.

General Somatic Afferent (GSA) fibres (Option C):

  • GSA fibres carry general sensory information such as touch, pain, and temperature from the skin and mucous membranes of the head and neck.
  • They do not transmit special senses like taste.

 

General Visceral Afferent (GVA) fibres (Option D):

  • GVA fibres convey sensory information from internal organs (viscera) such as distension, pressure, and pain.
  • They are not involved in transmitting taste or other special sensory modalities.

questions.text: What is the primary function of the alar plate in the developing neural tube?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Processing sensory information

Explanation:

The alar plate is involved in developing sensory nuclei, which process sensory information such as pain, touch, and proprioception, as well as special sensory modalities like taste, hearing, and vision. They give rise to

  • Special Somatic Afferent (SSA) fibres
  • Special Visceral Afferent (SVA) fibres
  • General Somatic Afferent (GSA) fibres
  • General Visceral Afferent (GVA) fibres

Development of motor nuclei (Option A): The development of motor nuclei is linked to the basal plate, not the alar plate, which primarily focuses on sensory processing.

 

Formation of autonomic motor fibres (Option C): Autonomic motor fibres originate from the basal plate and are part of the general visceral efferent (GVE) system, not the alar plate.

 

Regulation of somatic motor output (Option D): Somatic motor output is regulated by motor neurons that arise from the basal plate, not the alar plate.

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerve nuclei originates from the General Visceral Efferent (GVE) column of the basal plate?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Edinger-Westphal nucleus

 

Explanation:

  • The Edinger-Westphal nucleus is part of the GVE column via the Oculomotor (III) nerve, responsible for functions like pupil constriction and accommodation.
  • Along with the Edinger-Westphal nucleus, The GVE column also involves the Salivatory nuclei (for saliva secretion) and the vagal nucleus (controls the heart, lungs, and digestive system)

The basal plate of the neural tube has motor function and gives rise to

  • General Somatic Efferent (GSE) fibres
  • Special Visceral Efferent (SVE) fibres
  • General Visceral Efferent (GVE) fibres

Hypoglossal nucleus (Option B): The hypoglossal nucleus belongs to the General Somatic Efferent (GSE) column and controls voluntary movements of the tongue.

 

Facial nucleus (Option C): The facial nucleus is part of the Special Visceral Efferent (SVE) column and controls facial muscles, not autonomic functions.

 

The cochlear nucleus (Option D): The cochlear nucleus is involved in sensory functions related to hearing and originates from the Special Somatic Afferent (SSA) column, not the GVE column.

questions.text: A 5 year old boy came with complaints of sudden onset weakness in his lower limbs. His parents mention a history of viral illness with fever and sore throat. On examination, the boy has flaccid paralysis of his legs with muscle wasting, absent deep tendon reflexes, and no sensory deficits. Which of the following structures is primarily affected in this condition, leading to muscle paralysis and wasting?

choices.text: Posterior white columns of the spinal cord
Anterior grey columns of the spinal cord

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Anterior grey columns of the spinal cord

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario of this child points to a diagnosis of poliomyelitis due to the history of acute flaccid paralysis following fever and lower motor neuron involvement.
  • Poliomyelitis primarily affects the anterior grey columns, leading to lower motor neuron damage, causing muscle paralysis and wasting.

Poliomyelitis:

  • Viral infection of anterior grey columns of the spinal cord and cranial nerve motor nuclei.
  • Causes muscle paralysis and wasting, often affecting lower limbs more. Severe cases can impair respiration and affect facial, pharyngeal, laryngeal, and tongue muscles.
  • It is a lower motor neuron palsy.

 

Posterior white columns of the spinal cord (Option A): These columns are responsible for sensory functions, not motor control.

Spinothalamic tract (Option C): This tract transmits sensory information related to pain and temperature, not motor function.

Cerebellar peduncles (Option D): These are involved in coordinating movement, not directly causing paralysis associated with poliomyelitis.
